metadata.title: Strong effect of socioeconomic levels on the spread and treatment of the 2019 novel 1 coronavirus (COVID-19) in China

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted April 29, 2020. delivers array of cybersecurity challenges, i.e., overload the healthcare system and disrupt the 82 socioeconomic system 6-8 . The global response to the COVID-19 epidemic presents strengths 83 and weaknesses in national and regional social governance capacities to address public health 84 challenges. The emergence, detection, spread, treatment and containment of infectious diseases 85 shows the considerable political and economic impacts in a highly interconnected world 9 . 86 Understanding how the socioeconomic levels respond to the spread and treatment of COVID- 87 19 is of great significance for the success of combating the coronavirus epidemic. 88 Social and economic circumstances affect the spread and treatment of infectious diseases. 89 Conventionally, social governance measures, such as travel ban, social distancing and 90 gathering reduction, play a major role in preventing and controlling the rapid spread of the 91 epidemic in response to public health emergencies 10 . COVID-19 continues to immediately 92 spread through migration-this was the case in Wuhan of China at the beginning of the pandemic 93 and is now the cases all over China and the World 5,11 . Population migration and mobility is 94 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted April 29, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.25.20079400 doi: medRxiv preprint 6 linked to increases in economic growth, wages, income and innovation as well as virus 95 spread 12, 13 . The lockdown of cities was adopted by many countries in succession after Wuhan 96 was closed on 23 January 2020 14 . This measure aimed to mitigate the spread of COVID-19 and The disruption of the health care systems led to a low rate of cure, high severity and mortality 108 rates of the COVID-19 patients 7 . Furthermore, COVID-19 pandemic is likely to cause the 109 disruption of basic medical services and emergency facilities, the de-prioritisation of treatment 110 for other life-threatening diseases, conditions and for other chronic infectious diseases (e.g., 111 cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases, tuberculosis and malignancy) everywhere but 112 especially in some developing economies, where the health system is already fragile 16 . Thus, 113 improved understanding of the spread and treatment capacities of COVID-19 that affected by 114 socioeconomic levels is crucial to examining the effectiveness of control interventions.
In this study, we aim to estimate the effects of socioeconomic levels on the spread and 116 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

Starting on February 24, 2020, the response levels of public health downgraded outside Hubei.

Chinese government adopted intensive measures to contain COVID-19. i.e., Wuhan 198 lockdown, movement restriction and home self-isolation, masking in public, national joint 199 prevention and control, information disclosure, timely and sufficient COVID-19 detection.

Masking in public is to protect oneself from infection. Since COVID-19 was proved to be 201 transmitted mainly through droplets, wearing a mask is effective in preventing virus 202 transmission. National joint prevention and control was launched down to the community level.
Information transparency was guaranteed. i. e., real-time announcement of the number of 204 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF0.text: migration started across China. After Wuhan lockdown, the case number reached peak in 12 23 days, and COVID-19 outbreak was basically contained in China in four weeks due to intensive 24 measures. Guangdong, Jiangsu and Zhejiang Provinces showed the most excellent COVID-19 25 treatment capacities. Socioeconomic levels in these provinces ranked top in China. Guangdong 26 achieved the largest decline in severe case rate by 22.1%. Jiangsu had the lowest average rate 27 of severe cases (1.7%) and zero death. Among the regions with top case number, Zhejiang28

FIGREF1.text: Socioeconomic levels had strong effect on the spread and treatment of COVID-32 19 in China. Further investigations are needed on the effectiveness of Chinese measures and 33 the effects of socioeconomic levels on COVID-19 treatment outside China. Guangdong

FIGREF2.text: 67 strategies of COVID-19 or other epidemic. Further efforts are needed on the effectiveness of 68 Chinese management measures and the effects of socioeconomic levels on COVID-19 69 treatment outside China.

FIGREF4.text: of China. From 31 December 2019 through 3 January 2020, a total of 44 cases 75 with novel coronavirus pneumonia (NCP) of unknown etiology were reported to the World 76 Health Organization (WHO) by the Chinese health authorities 1-3 . Confirmed cases were 77 consecutively reported in 34 provinces, municipalities, and special administrative regions in 78 China 4 . As of 20 April 2020, there have been 8,4201 confirmed cases of COVID-19 infection 79 and 4642 deaths in China. Outside China, there have been 2,157,577 cases and 147,909 deaths 80 in at least 215 countries and regions 5 . The COVID-19 pandemic is sweeping the world and81

FIGREF5.text: 97 limit the number of patients that health systems have to manage. The most recent studies show 98 that approximately 15-20 per cent of patients with COVID-19 require hospitalisation and six 99 per cent require intensive care for a duration of between 3 and 6 weeks. Confirmation of the 100 COVID-19 diagnosis requires laboratory and/or medical imaging capabilities that are only 101 available in reference structures, like teaching hospitals 15 . Even in wealthy nations, U.S. and 102 EU, they have strong, well-funded health services and the hospital system was quickly 103 overwhelmed by the rapid increase in COVID-19 cases. Many poorer nations in Africa and 104 Asia, such as Pakistan and Iraq, are facing larger difficulties 3 . These countries are equipped 105 with under-developed infrastructure, inadequate pathogen detection capability and poor health 106 care service, and they cannot afford the fewer patients in comparison with developed nations.

FIGREF7.text: migration from Wuhan and the other cities in Hubei Province on a daily basis 152 were obtained from Qianxi Baidu website (https://qianxi.baidu.com/), ranging from January 1 153 to January 28 in 2019 and 2020. The top 20 cities in the migration size were assessed. 154 Macroeconomic data were collected from two levels: city and province level. At the 155 province level, the data from the 31 provinces, municipalities and autonomous regions outside 156 Hubei Province were obtained from China health statistics yearbook in 2019, and comprised 157 the indicators of population, total health expenditure (billion Yuan), gross domestic product 158 (GDP) (billion Yuan), total health expenditure in GDP (%), No. of hospitals, No. of top 159 hospitals, No. of doctors, No. of nurses, No. of beds in general hospitals, and public expenditure 160 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF8.text: Yuan). At the city level, the data were obtained from China city statistics yearbook in 161 2019, and were available for the 292 cities outside Hubei Province. These data comprised the 162 indicators of population, GDP (billion Yuan), No. of hospitals, No. of doctors, No. of hospital 163 beds, and public expenditure (billion Yuan). The statistical indicators of macroeconomic and 164 medical resource data at different levels were different. Spatial patterns of the indicators 165 representing macroeconomic levels at city and province levels in China were illustrated using 166 Arcgis Desktop 10.2 (Figure 7, 8 and 9). As the COVID-19 outbreak overloaded the health 167 care system in Hubei Province, and a total number of 3,8478 health care workers in other 168 provinces, municipalities and autonomous regions of China assisted Hubei (Chinese Health 169 commission news). The treatment capacity in Hubei Province is difficult to be evaluated.

FIGREF9.text: Therefore, Hubei Province was excluded to estimate the effects of regional socioeconomics on171 the COVID-19 treatment. Spatial pattern of the number of health care workers in other 172 provinces, municipalities and autonomous regions of China that assisted Hubei were illustrated 173 using Arcgis Desktop 10.2 (Figure 6). 174 2.3 Social management measures in response to COVID-19 epidemiologic pattern 175 Social management measures in response to COVID-19 epidemiologic patterns were 176 illustrated in Figure 1. On December 31, 2019, a cluster of pneumonia cases with unknown 177 etiology were reported in Wuhan, Hubei province, China, which attracted great attention of 178 health authorities. Wuhan Health Commission (WHC) declared novel coronavirus pneumonia 179 (NCP) outbreak, and National Health Commission (NHC) China and Chinese CDC 180 participated in investigation and response. The epidemiologic investigation pointed out that the 181 case infection may be associated with exposures in Huanan Seafood Market in Wuhan. On

FIGREF11.text: viral pneumonia among affected individuals was identified as a new coronavirus 184 COVID-19. On January 15, 2020, China CDC started the public health emergency response 185 level to Level 1 (the highest level). On January 20, 2020, COVID-19 was identified as a 186 statutory B infectious disease in China. Human to human transmission was confirmed by 187 Zhongnanshan, MD. Wuhan is located in central China and has a wide range of transportation 188 links, including airplanes, trains, interstate buses, and private transportation. On January 23, 189 2020, Wuhan was closed to prevent and control COVID-19 spread. On January 24-28, 2020, 190 the other cities in Hubei province were closed in succession. On January 27, 2020, Lunar New 191 Year national holiday was extended. On January 29, 2020, 31 provinces, municipalities and 192 regions in China started primary response to major public health, and return to work and school 193 across China was delayed. On February 13, 2020, the number of clinically diagnosed cases of 194 COVID-19 was included in Hubei Province, and the number of confirmed cases increased 195

FIGREF12.text: suspected cases every day in each city across China. COVID-19 was detected 205 timely and quantitatively. Nucleic acid detection was carried out in all close contact including 206 those without symptoms. Four early strategies were suggested: early protection (social 207 distancing), early detection, early diagnosis, and early isolation. Management measures 208 targeting COVID-19 treatment comprised: four early strategies, Fangcang shelter hospital 209 construction, health care assistance from other regions of China to Hubei, and determination 210 of designated hospitals for the COVID-19 treatment. of COVID-19 outbreak in China were identified at the city and 213 province levels on a daily basis. The outbreak period ranged from December 8, 2019, the date 214 of case onset to February 24, 2020, the date of notable case decrease. The number of daily 215 confirmed cases in China that were linked and unlinked to Huanan Seafood Market were 216 plotted by the date of diagnosis. At four key time nodes of COVID-19 outbreak, January 27, February 4, and February 24, 2020, the number of confirmed and suspected cases 218 in the 34 provinces (including Hubei), municipalities and regions were illustrated (Figure 1). 219 Spatial patterns of confirmed cases at a city level across China on January 27, February 4 and 220 March 4, 2020 were presented using Arcgis Desktop 10.2 (Figure 2). 221 To assess the effects of management measures on COVID-19 spread, COVID-19 222 epidemiologic curve was made by the dates of the milestones that were associated with 223 management measures. The impact of management measures on COVID-19 related migration 224 in Wuhan, Huanggang, Jingzhou and Xiaogan cities in Hubei province were examined.

FIGREF14.text: 228 this period because a significant increase in migration size occurred in Wuhan in 2020 in 229 comparison with that in 2019. The management measures responded COVID-19 outbreak in 230 Wuhan that may cause the abnormal increase in migration. Specifically, On January 1, 2020, 231 The Huanan Seafood Market was closed because of COVID-19 outbreak. On January 8, 2020, 232 the pathogen was identified as COVID-19. On January 15, 2020, China CDC started the public 233 health emergency response level to Level 1. On January 20, 2020, COVID-19 was identified 234 as a statutory B infectious disease in China, and human to human transmission was first 235 confirmed. On January 23, 2020, Wuhan was closed. On January 24-28, 2020, other cities in 236 Hubei province were closed in succession. These dates were the milestones when significant 237 changes in the time series of migration scale index for Wuhan were identified. We thus divided 238 the period, January 1 to 28, into five sub-periods: January 1 to 8, January 9 to 15, January 16 239 to 20, January 21 to 23 and January 24 to 28. The correlations between migration scale index 240 in Wuhan, Huanggang, Jingzhou and Xiaogan cities in these five sub-periods and confirmed 241 cases in China (outside Hubei province) on January 27, February 4 and March 4, 2020 were 242 calculated. Huanggang, Jingzhou and Xiaogan cities were used because the migration scale 243 index of these cities in Hubei province during the same period ranked secondary to Wuhan. 244 There may be potential risk of COVID-19 spread in Huanggang, Jingzhou and Xiaogan cities 245 through migration. Sankey maps of migration from Wuhan, Huanggang, Jingzhou and Xiaogan 246 cities to top 20 cities for the five sub-periods were obtained using ECHARTS 4.7.0.

FIGREF16.text: scale index, and Nij denotes the number of population 250 migrated from departure city i to destination city j, and Nt denotes the total number of 251 migration from departure city i. 252 To assess the effects of socioeconomic levels on COVID-19 treatment across China, we 253 examined the correlation between socioeconomic levels and confirmed cases, cured cases and 254 the rate of severe cases at the city and province levels (with an α value of 0.05). Hubei province 255 was excluded. Economic levels related to health care were described including population, total 256 health expenditure (billion Yuan), GDP (billion Yuan), total health expenditure in GDP (%), 257 the number of hospitals, the number of top hospitals, the number of doctors, the number of 258 nurses, the number of beds in general hospitals, and public expenditure (billion Yuan). Spatial 259 patterns of the number of confirmed and cured cases and the rates of severe cases across 31 260 regions and 292 cities of China as of March 4, 2020 were presented using Arcgis Desktop 10.2.261For each province, the rate of severe cases was calculated as follows: severe and confirmed cases in province i, respectively. Here, the number of severe cases 265 consisted of severe and critical cases. Hubei province were excluded from the calculation of 266 the rate of severe cases. The average rate of severe cases in the provinces, municipalities and 267 autonomous regions outside Hubei Province from January 21 to March 7, 2020 was calculated.

FIGREF17.text: COVID-19 cases indicates an exponential growth by human to human transmission 272 since late December, 2019, and a slight decline from January 9, 2020. This decline was not an 273 inflection point but due to the time lag between infection and diagnosis. An average incubation 274 period was 1 to 14 days 19 , and the COVID-19 suspected cases were diagnosed by viral nucleic 275 acid testing. The first epidemic peak occurred on January 8, 2020, and the cases focused in 276 Wuhan. Starting on January 20, 2020, the case number indicates an explosive increase 277 nationwide, and the second epidemic peak occurred on January 27. On 31 January, a total of 278 875 confirmed cases, 0.07/100,000 person all over China outside Hubei Province was shown. 279 The case number continued to boom, and the third epidemic peak occurred on February 4 (3156 280 laboratory-confirmed cases, 5.33/100,000 person in Hubei Province). Afterwards, the cases 281 gradually reduced. Notably, on February 12 and 13, the case peak was not real but due to the 282 number of clinically diagnosed cases was included in Hubei Province. As of February 24, the 283 cases were reported across 319 cities of 34 provinces, municipalities and autonomous regions 284 in China. After Wuhan lockdown, the number of cases reached peak in 12 days, and the 285 COVID-19 pandemic was basically contained in China in four weeks (Figure 1). 286 Temporal and spatial patterns of suspected and confirmed cases at a province level show 287 that outside Hubei Province, top five provinces in the number of confirmed cases were 288 presented in a decreasing order: Guangdong, Henan, Zhejiang, Hunan and Anhui Province.

FIGREF19.text: geographical agglomeration. Wuhan was the single center of agglomeration, and 294 the cases gradually reduced with the increase of geographical distance within a certain range. 295 The cases in Wuhan had an extremely strong connection with those in other cities of Hubei, 296 and had the largest radiation range in Hubei. Additionally, the cases in Wuhan had a strong 297 radiation range in other provinces, and indicate a strong connection with the neighborhood 298 cities and the major cities in other provinces. Regarding the grades of the case number, the 299 differences in the grade gradients between cities were obvious.

FIGREF20.text: Effect of social management measures and migration on the COVID-19 spread in China 301 A total number of 4.3 million people left from Wuhan between January 11 and 23, 2020 11 . 302 On January 23, Wuhan was closed, by that time, approximately 5 million people had already 303 left for hometowns for the Chinese Lunar New Year, for holidays, and for keeping away from 304 COVID-19 20 . From January 1 to 10, 2020, a total number of 0.7 million people was assessed 305 to leave from Wuhan. Migration from Wuhan indicates an abnormal increase since January 1, 306 2020 in comparison with that during the same period in 2019. Migration from other cities in 307 Hubei does not indicate an abnormal increase (Figure 3). The migrations from Wuhan in five

FIGREF22.text: 310WHC declared COVID-19 outbreak and Huanan Seafood Market was closed on December 31,311 2019 and January 1, 2020, respectively. On January 8, 2020, COVID-19 was identified as the 312 pathogen. Due to fear of COVID-19, migration from Wuhan indicates an abnormal increase in 313 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF23.text: that during the same period in 2019. The second sub-period was for the first 314 COVID-19 epidemic peak between January 8 and 15, 2020. During the period, China CDC 315 started public emergency response level to the highest level. Migration from Wuhan indicates 316 a mild fluctuation, however still an abnormal increase in comparison with that during the same 317 period in 2019. Migration from Wuhan reached the first peak on January 8, 2020 due to 318 increasing fear of COVID-19. The third sub-period between January 16 and 20, 2020 was for 319 the COVID-19 turning phase from Wuhan to the whole China. During the period, COVID-19 320 was identified as a statutory B infectious disease in China. On January 20, human to human 321 transmission was confirmed, and population started to flee from Wuhan. The fourth sub-period 322 was for the COVID-19 outbreak across China between January 21 and 24, 2020. Migration 323 indicates a sharp increase in comparison with that during the same period in 2019, and peaked 324 on January 23, which was the date Wuhan was closed. The fifth sub-period was between 325 January 24 and 28, 2020. During the period, other cities in Hubei were closed. Migration from 326 Wuhan and other cities in Hubei gradually fell to zero. 327 The average migration scale index of Wuhan in the five sub-periods were 5.4, 6.5, 7.2, 11.2, 328 and 1.3, respectively (Figure 3). As shown in Figure 4, top 20 hot destination cities that 329 migrated from Wuhan for these sub-periods were Changsha, Chongqing, Beijing, Xinyang, 330 Shanghai, Zhengzhou, Guangzhou, Chengdu, Shenzhen, Jiujiang, Yueyang, Nanyang, 331 Changde, Zhumadian, Nanchang, Nanjing, Hefei, Dongguan, Fuyang, and Zhoukou. These 332 cities were also the top destination cities that migrated from other cities in Hubei for the same 333 period. Migration from Wuhan had a strong radiation range in other provinces, and indicates a 334 strong connection with the neighborhood cities and the major cities in other provinces. Spatial 335 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF24.text: migration in Wuhan and other cities in Hubei were consistent with those of 336 confirmed cases outside Hubei. A large number of COVID-19 carriers gradually migrated from 337 Wuhan during the five sub-periods, and many people in other cities in Hubei, other provinces, 338 municipalities or autonomous regions of China were infected by close contact with these 339 migration. The cases that occurred in December 2019 were likely to be a small-scale exposure 340 transmission mode in Wuhan, and since January 2020, the cases were likely to be a spread 341 transmission mode in China. 342 Temporal patterns of migration in Wuhan, Huanggang, Jingzhou and Xiaogan cities in 343 Hubei indicate significantly positive correlation with those of the case number outside Hubei 344 of China (Table 1). Migration scale indices between January 1 and 8, 9 and 15, 16 and 20, 21 345 and 23 from Wuhan were significantly correlated with confirmed cases outside Hubei on 346 January 27, February 4 and March 4 (p<0.01) (Table 1). Among the correlations, migration 347 scale indices between January 1 and 8, 9 and 15 from Wuhan were best correlated with 348 confirmed cases outside Hubei on January 27, and the correlation coefficients r were 0.75 and 349 0.76, respectively (p<0.01). Migration scale indices between January 24 and 28 from 350 Huanggang, Jingzhou and Xiaogan cities indicate significant correlations with confirmed cases 351 outside Hubei. The correlations between confirmed cases and migration were found to be a 352 time lag of approximately 20-30 days or even 50-60 days, while the incubation period of 353 COVID-19 was estimated to be 1-14 days in general 19 . Thus, the COVID-19 outbreak outside 354 Hubei of China was delayed due to the effects of a series of social management measures. The 355 analysis above suggests that since January 1, 2020, 23 days before Wuhan lockdown, the 356 COVID-19 spread that affected by social management measures and migration started across 357 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF25.text: of socioeconomic levels on the COVID-19 treatment in China 361 Outside Hubei Province, confirmed and cured patients were significantly positively 362 correlated with population, GDP, public expenditure, the number of hospitals, hospital beds 363 and doctors at a city level (p<0.01) (Table 2). At a province level, confirmed and cured cases 364 were well positively correlated with total health expenditure and the share in GDP, GDP, 365 public expenditure, the number of hospitals, top hospitals, beds in general hospitals, nurses 366 and doctors (p<0.01) (Table 3). Spatial patterns of confirmed and cured patients indicate 367 good spatial consistency with those of population, GDP, public expenditure, the number of 368 hospitals, hospital beds and doctors at a city level (Figure 7). Similarly, spatial patterns of 369 confirmed and cured patients indicate good spatial consistency with those of total health 370 expenditure and the share in GDP, GDP, public expenditure, the number of hospitals, top 371 hospitals, beds in general hospitals, nurses and doctors at a province level (Figure 7 and 8).

FIGREF26.text: 372The rate of severe cases was negatively correlated with total health expenditure, GDP and 373 the number of doctors and nurses (p<0.05) (Table 3). Spatial pattern of the severe rates374 indicates good spatial consistency with that of total health expenditure, GDP and the number 375 of doctors and nurses at a province level. Top average rates of severe cases were presented in 376 a decreasing order: Tianjin city (26.9%), Xinjiang (22.6%), Anhui Province (19.2%), Hunan 377 Province (14.5%), Heilongjiang Province (14.2%), Liaoning Province (13.7%) and Qinghai378

FIGREF27.text: respectively. Xinjiang had the highest rate of death on confirmed cases and the second 382 high rate of severe cases in China (Figure 5). The regions with high rates of severe cases were 383 also the regions that invested the least fund in health care in China. Qinghai Province, Tianjin 384 City, Xinjiang, Gansu Province and Hainan Province that were equipped with the least number 385 of doctors and nurses at a province level in China, had relatively high rates of severe cases. 386 Particularly in Qinghai province, the number of doctors and nurses were the least in China, 387 with the values of 13725 and 17577, respectively. Qinghai Province also had the least GDP 388 among all regions in China. 389 Considering the number of confirmed, cured and death cases and the rates of severe cases, 390 the regions with the most confirmed cases (more than one thousand) were presented in a 391 decreasing order: Guangdong Province, Henan province, Zhejiang Province and Hunan 392 Province. Zhejiang and Guangdong showed the most excellent performance in COVID-19 393 treatment capacity. The highest rate of cured cases on the confirmed (96.3%), the lowest 394 average rate of severe cases (7.7%), and the fewest death, only one person in Zhejiang were 395 indicated. Guangdong achieved the largest decline in severe case rate from 31.8% to 9.7% in 396 China. The regions with the confirmed case number between 500 and 1000 were presented in 397 a decreasing order: Anhui Province, Jiangxi Province, Shandong Province, Jiangsu Province, 398 and Heilongjiang Province. Notably, Jiangsu had the lowest average rate of severe cases (1.7%) 399 and zero death among all regions in China. Guangdong, Jiangsu and Zhejiang Provinces, which 400 ranked the top three GDP in China, showed the most excellent treatment capacity of COVID-401 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF28.text: three provinces were equipped with relatively more abundant health care 402 resources and investment, and provided the most health care assistance to Hubei. The difference 403 in the number of health care workers that assisted Hubei roughly illustrates the difference in 404 health care levels among regions in China(Figure 6).

FIGREF29.text: of the socioeconomic levels on COVID-19 spread in China 407 Our results indicate that migration and management measures had a powerful impact on the 408 COVID-19 spread in China. Affected by a series of measures against COVID-19, e.g., the 409 announcement of a new virus outbreak, etiology identification, upgrade of public health 410 emergency level and confirmation of human to human transmission, an abnormal migration 411 from Wuhan occurred between January 1 and 23, 2020 due to fear of COVID-19. Temporal 412 and spatial patterns of migration from Wuhan were consistent with those of COVID-19 cases 413 outside Hubei. Starting on January 23, 2020, affected by management measures, e.g., Wuhan 414 lockdown, movement restriction and home stay throughout China, population mobility and 415 gatherings were reduced, thus containing COVID-19 spread in China. Additionally, Chinese 416 government launched a series of more intensive measures, e.g., wearing masks in public, 417 nationwide joint prevention and control to screening at a community level, four early strategies, 418 and information disclosure. These measures at various levels in China were superimposed, and 419 effectively controlled COVID-19 spread within four weeks after Wuhan lockdown. The 420 findings of Tian, Liu 11 based on modelling were similar to our results based on observational 421 data, and they found that the national emergency response appears to have delayed the growth 422 and limited the size of COVID-19 epidemic in China. With the rapid COVID-19 spread, the 423 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF30.text: of the socioeconomic levels on COVID-19 treatment in China 427 Our results suggest that social management measures on monitoring, communication, 428 response, research, epidemiologic survey and clinical practice adopted in China improved 429 COVID-19 treatment. For example, four early strategies, early protection (social distancing), 430 early detection, early diagnosis and early isolation, were implemented across China. As the 431 COVID-19 outbreak threatened to overload the healthcare system and disrupt the global 432 socioeconomic system. The aim of four early strategies is not only to reduce the case number 433 but also to spread them over time, avoiding congestion in health care system and intensive care 434 units. As is often the case during this type of pandemic, health care workers themselves are 435 particularly exposed to infection. Between mid-January and mid-February in China 1716 health 436 care workers were infected with COVID-19 (accounting for 3.8% of all patients) 17 . Four early 437 strategies, Fangcang shelter hospitals, medical assistance nationwide, and continuously 438 updated diagnosis and health care plan for COVID-19 were together carried out. These 439 strategies greatly improved COVID-19 treatment capacities in China, particularly in Hubei 440 Province. Specifically, confirmed, suspected patients and close contacts of confirmed patients 441 were identified, and these people were classified and managed in a centralized way. A large 442 number of mild cases were thus treated timely, and the possibility of turning into severe cases 443 was reduced 22 . These strategies laid a good foundation for increasing the cure rate and reducing 444 the mortality rate. The Fangcang shelter hospitals provided basic health care and clinical triage, 445 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF31.text: , moderate and severe patients were differently treated. It is suitable for the 446 management of a large number of patients and the burden on general hospitals was reduced.447 Time and economic cost of Fangcang shelter hospital construction is low 23 . With the 448 strengthening force of national medical support and treatment experience, health care resources 449 and capacities were greatly improved. 450 Our results suggest that COVID-19 treatment capacities outside Hubei in China were 451 greatly affected by regional socioeconomic levels. COVID-19 treatment capacities in 452 Guangdong, Jiangsu and Zhejiang Provinces ranked top three in China, which was consistent 453 with the GDP ranking. Strong economic support is the guarantee of health care level. Strong 454 health care level was the foundation of zero death and extremely low rate of severe cases in 455 Jiangsu Province. Despite a large number of COVID-19 confirmed cases (631 cases) in Jiangsu, 456 early detection, early treatment, and rapid recovery were achieved in the context of sufficient 457 healthcare resources, and the rate of severe cases was the lowest in China. Additionally, the 458 total number of medical members from Jiangsu assisting Hubei is 2,757, which was the largest 459 among the regions in China (Figure 6). The Jiangsu medical team took over treatment work in 460 Xiaogan City, Hubei Province, and focused on the intensive care units. The confirmed cases 461 (3518 cases) in Xiaogan was secondary to Wuhan in Hubei Province. In Wuhan, there were 462 five key hospitals that received the severe and critical patients. Jiangsu medical team 463 participated in three of these hospitals as the main force 24 . These aspects manifested powerful 464 treatment capability of Jiangsu Province.

FIGREF33.text: cases in Guangdong decreased the most by 22.1% among the regions in China. This 468 large decrease may be mainly due to continuously improved diagnosis and treatment 469 experience since COVID-19 outbreak. Guangdong established a comprehensive screening 470 system for the key COVID-19 cases. The screening team is composed of medical experts from 471 the Department of Infectious Diseases, Respiratory Medicine, Intensive Medicine, and Imaging. 472 This screen was performed on confirmed patients every day to examine if these patients had 473 the tendency to convert to severe or critical cases and take remedy measures. The number of 474 severe and critical cases was thus gradually declined. Besides, timely and effective publicity 475 measures were conducive to early detection of patients and avoided illness deterioration. 476 The excellent treatment capacity of COVID-19 in Zhejiang Province was mainly 477 presented from these aspects: early prevention and control, early development of detection 478 reagents, strong detection capability, and centralized treatment strategies. Specifically, 479 Zhejiang started the first level response of public health emergency and took the strictest 480 measures of joint prevention and control at the earliest. On January 10, 2020, Zhejiang 481 Provincial Health Commission carried out hospital-infection arrangements for hypothesized 482 epidemic outbreak in medical institutions across the province. Zhejiang CDC was the first 483 provincial disease control laboratory to successfully isolate COVID-19 coronavirus strains in 484 China, and an automated whole-genome detection and analysis platform was launched to speed 485 up COVID-19 detection. Many institutions in Zhejiang had the detection ability at the initial 486 phase of COVID-19 outbreak, with a daily detection capacity of 12,000 person. At the same 487 time, a third-party testing agency in Zhejiang undertook a total number of 75,000 nucleic acid 488 testing in neighboring provinces by mid-February 2020 25 . With the support of screening at 489 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF34.text: and nucleic acid detection, early treatment was achieved. Moreover, four 490 centralization strategies were adopted in treatment in Zhengjiang. Patients and medical 491 resources were centralized, and medical experts and treatment were centralized. Treatment was 492 centralized based on disease severity. The four centralization could save medical resources, 493 improve the treatment efficiency and the rate of cured cases, and reduce the rates of severe 494 cases and mortality. 495 Regarding COVID-19 detection, the above three provinces showed strong nucleic acid 496 detection capabilities and had the ability to assist the detection in other provinces of China. In 497 China, most of famous enterprises of nucleic acid detection kit development are located in 498 Guangdong, Jiangsu and Zhejiang Provinces, for instance, Jinyu and Huada in Guangdong, 499 Shuoshi and Suzhou Medical Workers in Jiangsu, Dean and Adicon in Zhejiang. To improve 500 detection efficiency, at the beginning of COVID-19 outbreak, a three-party joint test, "CDC + 501 medical institution + the third-party enterprise", was carried out in these three provinces. The 502 testing results could be produced on the same day, and there was no problem of backlog of 503 suspected patients due to timely diagnosis. Additionally, Tianjin city, Xinjiang and Qianghai 504 Province had higher rates of severe cases and mortality in comparison with other regions in 505 China. Because these regions had a relatively low level of economic investment in health care, 506 and the treatment capacities of COVID-19 were thus relatively poor.

FIGREF36.text: 508 treatment of COVID-19 in China. Future work on the individual effect of each management 509 measure on the spread and treatment of COVID-19 at a province level could be carried out 510 outside Hubei Province, both quantitatively and qualitatively. The effect of each management 511 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF37.text: be examined separately and the dominant measure could be examined. A 512 comparative analysis using control experiments and model simulation on the effects of these 513 management measures at a province or country scale could be performed. Additionally, the 514 limitation of this study lied in data unavailability. For an improved understanding of 515 socioeconomic effect on COVID-19 treatment in China, case reports of severe and dead 516 patients at a city level, including gender, age, weight, medical history and length of hospital 517 stay could be added. Socioeconomic factors, e.g., the number of beds, doctors and nurses in 518 intensive care units, the number of key medical resources in all top hospitals, e.g., negative 519 pressure ambulances, Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO), ventilator and other 520 key treatment equipment at a city level could be supplemented. COVID-19 spread in China 521 was effectively curbed, and the spread to other countries was notably reduced. The 522 effectiveness of these Chinese measures in controlling transmission and treatment of COVID-523 19 in other countries of the world requires intensive examination. The Chinese experience 524 provides important insights into how to design effective management strategies of COVID

FIGREF38.text: workers who are fighting on the front line of the prevention and control of COVID-19 533 all over the world. Thank you very much to all the staff who participated in the prevention and 534 control of COVID-19, including treatment, detection and diagnosis, epidemiologic 535 investigation, close contact management, and scientific research, etc.

The number of daily confirmed cases that were linked (blue) and 595 unlinked (pink) to Huanan Seafood Market were plotted by the date of diagnosis. The time 596 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

TABREF0.text: treatment of the COVID-19 in China. The spatial and temporal patterns of the spread and treatment of the COVID-19 at city and province levels across China were identified. The effects 118 of social management measures and migration on COVID-19 spread, and the effects of management measures and economic levels on COVID-19 treatment were assessed. From December 31, 2019, the centers of disease control (CDC)s at all levels in China jointly launched the COVID-19 investigation. COVID-19 was identified as a statutory B infectious 124 disease in China on January 20, 2020. Legally, all cases were required to be reported 125 immediately through the Infectious Disease Information System (IDIS). Individual case 126 information was submitted into the system by local hospitals and CDC personnel who 127 investigated and collected possible exposure information. All case records have personal identification numbers, and all cases are not duplicated in the system. We collected the COVID-19 cases on a daily basis that reported by the CDCs at all levels as of March 4, 2020, in the cities of 31 provinces, municipals and autonomous regions in Mainland China. These 131 data and management measures were obtained from the websites of local health commissions.All cases were included in this study, and the sampling of a predetermined sample size was not required, and the case inclusion criteria was not considered 17 .Terms with respect to COVID-19 cases in China were defined based on treatment plan of COVID-19 that issued by Chinese authorities 17,18 . If the case has been in close contact with the Huanan Seafood Market, who was identified as an exposure linked to the Huanan Seafood

TABREF1.text: were not our focus. We focused on confirmed cases, cured cases, and severe (i.e., severe and 139 critical) cases. Suspected cases were determined based on the symptoms (e.g., fever, cough, fatigue and diarrhea) and exposures (if the patient lived or traveled in Wuhan, or had close contact with a person who has been to Wuhan recently, who was identified as Wuhan related exposure) for clinical diagnosis. Confirmed cases referred to suspected cases with positive results of nucleic acid testing through respiratory tract samples (e.g., throat swabs). Clinically diagnosed cases were those suspected cases with pneumonia imaging features (only applicable in Hubei Province). Cured cases referred to the cases that were cured and discharged. Severe cases referred to the cases that manifest dyspnea with respiratory frequency ≥30 / min, blood 147 oxygen saturation ≤93%, PaO2 / FiO2 ratio <300, and / or lung infiltration> 50% within 24 to 148 48 hours. Critical cases referred to those cases with respiratory failure, septic shock and / or
